THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 20, 1922.
RECEPTION FOR OUT-OFTOWN MEN BIG SUCCESS
Hopkins men from foreign
'countries and from all parts of the
United States became acquainted
with the pastors and some of the
members of the churches in the vicinity of the University last Friday night, at an interdenominational meeting held at the Friends
Meeting House by the Hopkins
Y. M. C. A. and the Neighborhood
Churches. The reception was held
to bring the out-of-town student in
touch with the nearest church of his
own denomination.
The University men, led by John
Sherwood, started the meeting by
singing some Hopkins songs. The
Rev. Dr. Harris made the opening
prayer. Mr. Morriss, general secretary of the "Y", who acted as master of ceremonies, explained the
purpose of the reception. He said
he would like the students to know
that the Friends Meeting House.
with its library, is always open to
Hopkins men.
The ministers representing the
various denominations gave short
in the "that-reminds-Me"
talks
vein, while Mr: Morriss held the
stopwatch. One and all urged the
students to join a church and participate in the church life of whatever denomination they preferred.
The speakers were: The Rev. Dr.
Neilly, of the Waverly Presbyterian Church Rev. Dr. Morgan, of
the First Methodist Episcppal ;
Rev. Dr. Harris, of the Wilson Memorial M. E. South; Rev. Dr. Warner, of St. John's Methodist Prot estant ; Rev. Arrowsmith, of the
Pro-Cathedral; Rev. Dr. Clare, of
St. Mark's Lutheran; the Rev. Dr.
Dixon, wlihas just retnrucd.irom
China to take charge of the University Baptist Church, and Mr.
Louis Moon. secretary of the
Friends Meeting House.
• Dr. French, chairman of the Student Advisory Committee, pointed
out that American colleges supervise their students' mental training,
but not their moral, andlie thanked
those responsible for the meeting
for taking an interest in the latter.
He told the students that participation in community life, as well as
studies, was an important part of
their education.
At the close of the speeches refreshments were served, and the
students had a chance to meet the
church people who were present.

FIRST ISSUE OF BLACK AND
BLUE JAY TO APPEAR SOON
The first issue of the Black and
Blue Jay went to press Monday,
and will be distributed about October 27. It is the "Renaissance
Number," devoted to the "Revival
of Learning" (the return to college). Black and Blue Jay men are
now working on the "Fraternity
Number," and are on the trail of
laughs and low snickers concerning
the "Frats" and college life in general. Competition is developing
among the candidates for the staff,
and they will have to work hard.
The Black and Blue Jay wants
subscribers outside of the University. Subscription cards will be
placed in the P. 0. boxes along
with the first issue of the magazine. Students are asked to get
subscriptions from their numerous
friends.

DR. GILDEFtSLEEVE IS NINETY-ONE ON MONDAY
Dr. Gildersleeve, the noted
scholar and teacher, who retired
from the active duties of his professorship at thp Johns Hopkins
University not many years ago,
will celebrate his ninety-fir-st birthday this coming Monday, October
23. Fast nearing the one hundred
-nark, this well-known figure in national and international circles is
still active and healthy.
Unfortunately, the doctor's eyes
have given him trouble, so that he
is forced to rely, in part, upon his
friends and his memory for his associations with the classics which
he loves so well. However, he is
keeping steadily abreast of the
times and always a learned Greek
scholar, he now revels in the old
Greek classics, whose texts he reviews time and again in his sheer
'ove for and appreciation of their
)utstanding beauty.
The anniversary of Dr. Gildersleeve's birth will be passed in the
presence of only a few of his
closest friends.

Y. M. C. A. NOTICES
The Y. M. C. A. has gone to
considerable expense in the purchase of a number of magazine
covers, hoping to render current
magazines more durable and convenient for the benefit of the students. This purpose, however, is
being defeated by the fact that they
are sometimes removed from the
room in which they have been
placed. Hereafter please leave them
where you find them.
The Y. M. C. A. wishes to remind the student body that it is
running a Lost and Found Bureau,
and that the Association is anxious
to be of service in this respect. This
can only be accomplished, however,
by the co-operation of the students.
Please don't forget about it.

FACULTY NOTES
Dr. John Holladay Latane, Dean
of the College Faculty, is leaving
this week for South America,
where he will visit the Brazilian
Centennial Exposition held at Rio
de Janeiro, Brazil. In his absence
Dr. Joseph Elliott Gilpin, Collegiate
Professor of Chemistry, will act as
dean and will have the same conference hours, from 11:30 to 4:30,
at the office Of the Dean, Gilman
Hall.

NOTES ON STYLE
From delegates at. the National
Clothiers' Convention, being held
now in Chicago, comes the news
that trousers with a corset effect
will be the latest style in men's
clothes in the course of the next
few months. As a proof of this
prediction, models were exhibited
which are said to be capable of
placing man on an equal basis with
woman in this respect. A flexible
belt secured to each side of the
trousers is designed to fit closely
over the abdomen. When drawn
in and fastened, the arrangement
gives a decided corset-like appearance. Talk about the campus
s6ems to indicate that there will
be a heavy sale of the new style
trousers to the "he-flappers" who
are now prone to wear colored hat
bands on soft felt hats.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 20, 1922.
RECEPTION FOR OUT-OFTOWN MEN BIG SUCCESS
Hopkins men from foreign
'countries and from all parts of the
United States became acquainted
with the pastors and some of the
members of the churches in the vicinity of the University last Friday night, at an interdenominational meeting held at the Friends
Meeting House by the Hopkins
Y. M. C. A. and the Neighborhood
Churches. The reception was held
to bring the out-of-town student in
touch with the nearest church of his
own denomination.
The University men, led by John
Sherwood, started the meeting by
singing some Hopkins songs. The
Rev. Dr. Harris made the opening
prayer. Mr. Morriss, general secretary of the "Y", who acted as master of ceremonies, explained the
purpose of the reception. He said
he would like the students to know
that the Friends Meeting House.
with its library, is always open to
Hopkins men.
The ministers representing the
various denominations gave short
in the "that-reminds-Me"
talks
vein, while Mr: Morriss held the
stopwatch. One and all urged the
students to join a church and participate in the church life of whatever denomination they preferred.
The speakers were: The Rev. Dr.
Neilly, of the Waverly Presbyterian Church Rev. Dr. Morgan, of
the First Methodist Episcppal ;
Rev. Dr. Harris, of the Wilson Memorial M. E. South; Rev. Dr. Warner, of St. John's Methodist Prot estant ; Rev. Arrowsmith, of the
Pro-Cathedral; Rev. Dr. Clare, of
St. Mark's Lutheran; the Rev. Dr.
Dixon, wlihas just retnrucd.irom
China to take charge of the University Baptist Church, and Mr.
Louis Moon. secretary of the
Friends Meeting House.
• Dr. French, chairman of the Student Advisory Committee, pointed
out that American colleges supervise their students' mental training,
but not their moral, andlie thanked
those responsible for the meeting
for taking an interest in the latter.
He told the students that participation in community life, as well as
studies, was an important part of
their education.
At the close of the speeches refreshments were served, and the
students had a chance to meet the
church people who were present.

FIRST ISSUE OF BLACK AND
BLUE JAY TO APPEAR SOON
The first issue of the Black and
Blue Jay went to press Monday,
and will be distributed about October 27. It is the "Renaissance
Number," devoted to the "Revival
of Learning" (the return to college). Black and Blue Jay men are
now working on the "Fraternity
Number," and are on the trail of
laughs and low snickers concerning
the "Frats" and college life in general. Competition is developing
among the candidates for the staff,
and they will have to work hard.
The Black and Blue Jay wants
subscribers outside of the University. Subscription cards will be
placed in the P. 0. boxes along
with the first issue of the magazine. Students are asked to get
subscriptions from their numerous
friends.

DR. GILDEFtSLEEVE IS NINETY-ONE ON MONDAY
Dr. Gildersleeve, the noted
scholar and teacher, who retired
from the active duties of his professorship at thp Johns Hopkins
University not many years ago,
will celebrate his ninety-fir-st birthday this coming Monday, October
23. Fast nearing the one hundred
-nark, this well-known figure in national and international circles is
still active and healthy.
Unfortunately, the doctor's eyes
have given him trouble, so that he
is forced to rely, in part, upon his
friends and his memory for his associations with the classics which
he loves so well. However, he is
keeping steadily abreast of the
times and always a learned Greek
scholar, he now revels in the old
Greek classics, whose texts he reviews time and again in his sheer
'ove for and appreciation of their
)utstanding beauty.
The anniversary of Dr. Gildersleeve's birth will be passed in the
presence of only a few of his
closest friends.

Y. M. C. A. NOTICES
The Y. M. C. A. has gone to
considerable expense in the purchase of a number of magazine
covers, hoping to render current
magazines more durable and convenient for the benefit of the students. This purpose, however, is
being defeated by the fact that they
are sometimes removed from the
room in which they have been
placed. Hereafter please leave them
where you find them.
The Y. M. C. A. wishes to remind the student body that it is
running a Lost and Found Bureau,
and that the Association is anxious
to be of service in this respect. This
can only be accomplished, however,
by the co-operation of the students.
Please don't forget about it.

FACULTY NOTES
Dr. John Holladay Latane, Dean
of the College Faculty, is leaving
this week for South America,
where he will visit the Brazilian
Centennial Exposition held at Rio
de Janeiro, Brazil. In his absence
Dr. Joseph Elliott Gilpin, Collegiate
Professor of Chemistry, will act as
dean and will have the same conference hours, from 11:30 to 4:30,
at the office Of the Dean, Gilman
Hall.

NOTES ON STYLE
From delegates at. the National
Clothiers' Convention, being held
now in Chicago, comes the news
that trousers with a corset effect
will be the latest style in men's
clothes in the course of the next
few months. As a proof of this
prediction, models were exhibited
which are said to be capable of
placing man on an equal basis with
woman in this respect. A flexible
belt secured to each side of the
trousers is designed to fit closely
over the abdomen. When drawn
in and fastened, the arrangement
gives a decided corset-like appearance. Talk about the campus
s6ems to indicate that there will
be a heavy sale of the new style
trousers to the "he-flappers" who
are now prone to wear colored hat
bands on soft felt hats.
